questions.question: Which of the following is not commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus?
questions.explanation: Acute pharyngitis is not commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, it is more commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or viral pathogens.

questions.question: Anu, a pre-school student presented with a fever and sore throat. She also had an acute onsetgeneralized erythematous rash with pastia lines over the antecubital fossa. What is the mostlikely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of scarlet fever.Scarlet fever is a delayed type of skin reaction to streptococcal exotoxin and occurs as acomplication of streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis. There is a diffuse erythematous maculopapularrash, which blanches on pressure. This gives a sandpaper quality to the skin.A characteristic physical finding in which red or pink petechial lines appear in skin creases iscalled Pastia's sign, Pastia lines, or Thompson's sign.The image below shows Pastia lines in the antecubital fossa.308

questions.question: 296A young boy is brought to the OPD with a sore throat and a rash, which appears as shown inthe image, for the past 2 days. The rash started around the neck and then spread to the trunkand extremities. On examination, rash blanches on pressure. Tongue examination showsswollen papillae. Which of the following toxins is responsible for this child's condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of scarlet fever, which is caused by a pyrogenic exotoxinproduced by Group A streptococcus (GAS).In scarlet fever, the rash appears within 24-48 hours of the onset of upper respiratory infections.It begins around the head and neck and spreads over the trunk and extremities. It usually sparespalms, and soles. It is a diffuse, papular, and erythematous eruption, which blanches onpressure. The cheeks are erythematous, with pallor around the mouth. The tongue is usuallycoated, and the papillae are swollen, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance.The image below shows a strawberry tongue.309

questions.question: A 7-year-old child abruptly developed symptoms suggestive of obsessive-compulsive disorderand Tourette syndrome. PANDAS, a pediatric neuropsychiatric disorder, is suspected. Whichof the following organisms is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: PANDAS is associated with Streptococcus pyogenes infection.PANDAS stands for Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated withStreptococcal infections.The symptoms usually occur abruptly and can include the following:• Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)• Tic disorder• Gilles de la Tourette syndrome (coprolalia and tics)Additionally, children may become moody or irritable, experience anxiety attacks, and/or showseparation anxiety. These symptoms are the result of an autoimmune process that leads toinflammation of the basal ganglia and the resultant disruption of cortical-striatal-thalamic axisfunctioning.•Features:Prepubertal onset• Abrupt and episodic course•Neurological symptomsDisorders associated: Tics, OCD• Associated with a recent history of sore throatNote: Non-infectious manifestations of streptococcal infection:• Rheumatic heart disease•Glomerulonephritis• PANDAS• Guttate psoriasis

questions.question: Which of the following is a major criterion in the revised Jones criteria used for the diagnosisof acute rheumatic fever in high-risk populations?297
questions.explanation: Polyarthralgia is a major criterion in the revised Jones criteria used for the diagnosis of acuterheumatic fever in high-risk populations (ARF incidence >2 per 100 000 school-aged childrenor all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of >1 per 1000 population per year).Strict adherence to the Jones criteria in areas of higher prevalence may result in under-diagnosis.Therefore, the criteria are slightly modified for moderate to high-risk populations as follows:•The major criterion of arthritis includes polyarthralgia or monoarthritis in addition topolyarthritis. Polyarthralgia should only be considered as a major manifestation after theexclusion of other causes.• The minor criterion for joint involvement is monoarthralgia.• A lower cutoff for fever is used (≥38°C [100.4°F] rather than ≥38.5°C [101.3°F]).310• A lower cutoff for erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is used (≥30 mm/hour rather than≥60 mm/hour), although the C-reactive protein (CRP) cutoff is unchanged (≥3 mg/dL).

questions.question: A 10-year-old girl presents with a 2-day history of fever and joint pain. Further questioningreveals that she had a sore throat 3 weeks back for which she did not seek medical help. Acuterheumatic fever is suspected. Which of the following is not a component of the criteria usedfor the diagnosis of this child's condition?
questions.explanation: Erythema nodosum is not a component of Jones criteria which is used for acute rheumatic fever(ARF) diagnosis. Erythema marginatum is a major manifestation of the Jones criteria. It isan evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.The image below shows erythema marginatum.

questions.question: Which of the following constitutes Hutchinson's triad?

options.A: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars
options.B: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars
options.C: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors
options.D: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

questions.explanation: Hutchinson's triad refers to interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, and Hutchinson incisors. It isseen in late congenital syphilis.The image below shows Hutchinson incisors:311Congenital syphilis is due to Treponema pallidum. Early features include hepato-splenomegaly,jaundice, diffuse lymphadenopathy, maculopapular or vesiculobullous rash involving hands andfeet, persistent rhinitis (snuffles), and condylomatous lesions. Skeletal changes like saber shins,dental abnormalities like Hutchinson's teeth, and saddle nose (depression of the nasal root) aresome late findings.Other clinical features of congenital syphilis:⚫ Clutton joint - Due to synovitis, with sterile synovial fluid•⚫ Juvenile tabes and paresis••-Rhagades Linear scars radiating from mucocutaneous fissures of the mouth, anus, andgenitalia•Mulberry molars - Abnormal 1st lower molars with excessive cusps•Sabre shin - Anterior bowing of the mid-portion of the tibia.Olympian brow - Bony prominence of the forehead312

questions.question: A 1-year-old baby is brought to the paediatrician by his mother because of jaundice. Onexamination, the baby has hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. He has a saddle noseand persistent rhinitis as seen in the picture. The baby had been 2300g at birth. The deliverywas complicated by preterm labour and a single, painless ulcer with a clean base on themother's labia. Which of the following feature will not be seen in this baby?298
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital syphilis. Coombs-negative hemolytic anemiais a characteristic feature of congenital syphilis, not coombs-positive hemolytic anemia.Congenital syphilis results from transplacental transmission of Treponema pallidum or duringbirth by contact with infectious lesions of the mother.Clinical features of congenital syphilis:⚫ Hutchinson's triad - Hutchinson teeth, interstitial keratitis, sensorineural deafness•• Clutton joint - Due to synovitis, with sterile synovial fluid• Juvenile tabes and paresis-Rhagades Linear scars radiating from mucocutaneous fissures of the mouth, anus, andgenitalia.•Saddle nose - Depression of nasal bridgeMulberry molars - Abnormal 1st lower molars with excessive cusps• Sabre shin - Anterior bowing of the mid-portion of the tibia• Olympian brow - Bony prominence of the forehead• Snuffles Persistent rhinitis-

questions.question: A neonate was delivered via normal vaginal delivery. His mother was diagnosed with activetuberculosis infection during pregnancy but she refused treatment in fear of side effects to thebaby. If the baby had been infected prenatally, which of the following organs is most likely tobe involved?
questions.explanation: The liver is the most commonly involved organ in congenital tuberculosis.Primary infection in a female just before or during pregnancy is more likely to cause congenitaltuberculosis. Congenital transmission usually occurs from a lesion in the placenta through theumbilical vein. The tuberculous bacilli may pass through the umbilical vein and develop a hepaticfocus. Tuberculosis in neonates generally presents with respiratory distress,hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy.Note:The most common route of infection for a neonate is the postnatal airborne transmission from anadult with infectious pulmonary tuberculosis.

questions.question: A 12-year-old boy presented with a persistent cough. There was a contact history with anactive tuberculosis case in his neighborhood. His X-ray revealed prominent hilarlymphadenopathy as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is false regardingthis patient's condition?299

options.A: Puhl's lesion at the apex of lung is seen in primary infection
options.B: Most cases of pediatric TB are asymptomatic
options.C: Sputum smear-negative TB does not rule out pediatric pulmonary TB
options.D: The most common site of extrapulmonary TB is the lymph node

questions.explanation: The patient had exposure to an active tuberculosis case and has hilar lymphadenopathy (image),suggestive of primary tuberculosis. Puhl's lesion is chronic tuberculosis (TB) of the apex of thelung, not seen in the primary infection.313The majority of children develop no signs or symptoms at any level.In primary pulmonary disease, the combination of the parenchymal pulmonary lesion and thecorresponding lymph node is called Ghon's complex or the primary complex. Asymptomaticpleural effusion is common and forms part of the primary complex. Erosion of a parenchymalfocus of tuberculosis into the blood or lymphatic vessel can result in dissemination of the bacilliand a miliary pattern, with small nodules evenly distributed on the chest radiograph. Sputumsmear-negative TB does not rule out pediatric pulmonary TB.Chronic pulmonary tuberculosis is common in children above 7 years of age. The commonest siteis the apex of the lung―Puhl's lesion. Regional lymph nodes are not involved.The most common site of extrapulmonary tuberculosis in children is the lymph node.NOTE:• Ranke complex: Ghon's complex undergoes fibrosis and calcification.• Simon focus: Hematogenous spread to the apex of the upper lobe, resulting in a post-primaryinfective lesion, which heals with scarring.• Simmond's focus: Tuberculous focus in the liver.•Weigert focus: Caseating metastatic tuberculous focus in the wall of a pulmonary vein.• Rich focus: Tuberculous granuloma occurring in the cortex of the brain.

questions.question: A woman with smear-positive tuberculosis is on anti-tubercular therapy (ATT). She delivereda healthy male baby at term. How is the newborn managed in this case?

options.B: Breastfeeding + INH for 2 months then BCG vaccine
options.C: Breastfeeding + INH for 6 months then BCG vaccine
options.D: BCG + INH for 6 months + withhold Breastfeeding

questions.explanation: In a neonate born to a mother with smear-positive tuberculosis, breastfeeding along with INHprophylaxis for 3-6 months is recommended. BCG vaccine is recommended at birth or aftercompletion of prophylaxis (3-6 months) in all neonates.When a child is born to a mother with active TB, the main aim is the TB-free survival of thenewborn. It involves detecting active TB lesions (congenital TB) and treating them or preventionof transmission of tubercular infection to the neonate from the mother.Prophylaxis with isoniazid (3-6 months) is recommended in neonates born to mothers with TBwho are infectious (smear-positive). Breastfeeding should be continued in these neonates andisolation is recommended only till the mother is infectious, has multidrug-resistant tuberculosis,or nonadherent to treatment. BCG vaccine is recommended at birth or after completion ofprophylaxis (3-6 months) in all neonates. However, if the Mantoux test is positive and evidence ofdisease is found, ATT is started.

questions.question: A 25-year-old lady is detected to have active tuberculosis at 37 weeks of gestation. Shedelivers a baby girl 2 days later. As per NTEP guidelines, what advice is given immediatelyafter delivery?

options.A: INH prophylaxis to be given to the neonate for 6 weeks
options.B: Mother is to be started on ATT

questions.explanation: The mother with TB is advised to start ATT immediately irrespective of time of delivery.The management guidelines followed in a case of active TB in a mother immediately followingdelivery include:•Mother has to be started on ATT.314•Do not separate the baby from the mother.• Do not withhold breastfeeding.•Screening of household contacts.• Screen the neonate for congenital/active TB.In accordance with the NTEP 2020 guidelines, a newborn whose mother has active TB and is onATT should be managed with prophylactic isoniazid (INH) for 6 months, BCG vaccination atbirth, with the continuation of breastfeeding, after ruling out active TB.INH prophylaxis is given irrespective of the BCG or nutritional status. 10 mg/kg is administereddaily for a minimum of six months. During monthly tablet collection, the child should be closelymonitored for TB symptoms to rule out active TB and also assess for any INH-related adverseeffects.BCG vaccination can be given at birth even if INH preventive therapy is planned.In case the newborn is found to have active TB, ATT is to be initiated along with theadministration of BCG vaccine.

questions.question: A worried couple brought their 4-day-old baby to the pediatrician due to difficulty in feedingand abnormal posture. The baby was delivered at home and the mother never had a prenatalcheckup. On examination, the baby's body was rigid, with flexed upper limb and extendedback. The umbilical cord was covered with cow dung. The mother says it's their tradition, andthat the dirt helps with the falling off of the cord. Which of the following is false regardingthis condition?

options.A: The toxin responsible affects the excitatory neurons
options.B: Metronidazole is given as a treatment
options.C: It occurs in infants of unimmunized mothers

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neonatal tetanus. It is caused by a neurotoxin producedby Clostridium tetani, which inhibits inhibitory neurons, not excitatory neurons.Clostridium tetani is a spore-forming obligate anaerobe commonly found in soil, dust, andgastrointestinal tracts of various animals. The baby's umbilical stump covered with cow dungserves as the source of infection. It also occurs in infants of unimmunized mothers. Tetanustypically manifests within 3-12 days of birth as progressive difficulty in feeding, rigidity, orspasms.Tetanus toxin binds at the neuromuscular junction and enters the motor nerve; it is thentransported to the alpha-motoneuron via retrograde axonal transport. Subsequently, the toxinenters the adjacent spinal inhibitory interneurons, where it prevents the release of theneurotransmitters glycine and y-aminobutyric acid. This leads to blockade of normal antagonisticmuscle inhibition, while agonist muscles undergo sustained contraction without relaxing.Neonatal tetanus presents with progressive feeding difficulty (sucking and swallowing),irritability, and crying. Characteristic features include reduced movement or complete muscleparalysis, rigidity, and spasms. These features may or may not be associated with opisthotonos.Treatment includes supportive care in the form of muscle relaxants (diazepam), along with theadministration of human tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) and metronidazole, which is theantibiotic of choice. Parenteral penicillin G can serve as an alternate antibiotic.Excising the umbilical stump in a baby with neonatal tetanus is no longer recommended.

questions.question: A 6-year-old unvaccinated child presents with complaints of sore throat and difficulty inswallowing. The patient also has fever and hoarseness of voice and her facial appearance is asshown below. A provisional diagnosis of Diptheria is made. Which of the following statementsis true regarding this patient's condition?

options.A: It can be diagnosed by the demonstration of antibody by ELISA
options.C: Treatment of contacts is not indicated
options.D: Iron has a critical value in the production of toxins

questions.explanation: 315The image shows a bull-neck appearance due to the soft tissue edema, seen in diphtheria. Iron isessential for the production of toxins in diphtheria.It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Carriers are the most common causes of infection.Immunization does not prevent the carrier state. It spreads via droplets through the respiratorytract (most important), cutaneous lesions, and fomites.The regulation of toxin production in the bacterium is partially controlled by iron, thus making itan important prerequisite for toxin production.Clinical features:•••• Respiratory tract diphtheria (most common):Thick, adherent pseudomembrane (grey or white) on one/both tonsils and adjacent pharynx.Dislodging of the membrane may cause bleeding.Underlying soft tissue edema and enlarged lymph nodes can cause a bull-neck appearance• Patients with laryngeal diphtheria are at risk for suffocation because of local soft-tissue edemaand airway obstruction by the diphtheritic membrane.DAILYROUNDS•Cutaneous diphtheria is an indolent, non-progressive infection characterized by a superficial,ecthyma-like, non-healing ulcer with a gray-brown membrane.• Occasionally, it causes mucocutaneous infections at other sites, such as otitis externa, purulentconjunctivitis, and vulvo-vaginitis.Diagnosis: The culture of the organism from the nose and throat swab specimens is the goldstandard. Demonstration of the toxin is done by Elek's gel precipitation test. Gram stain andfluorescent antibody tests are unreliable.Complications include obstruction due to pseudomembrane, myocarditis, and polyneuropathy.

questions.question: A diphtheria screening camp is being held at a rural school to find carriers and to providethem adequate treatment. What is the investigation of choice in this scenario?
questions.explanation: 316The investigation of choice for diphtheria carriers is throat swab culture.Specimens for culture should be obtained from the nose and throat and any other mucocutaneouslesion. A portion of the membrane should be removed and sent for culture along with theunderlying exudate in those with overt disease. Direct smear using Gram stain or specificfluorescent antibody is unreliable.

questions.question: Anuj has been diagnosed with diphtheria and is being treated in the ward. His 3-year-oldbrother, Ajay who lives in the same house has received vaccination against diphtheria about16 months back. What is the next best step for the management of the younger sibling, Ajay?

options.B: Nothing as the child is already exposed

questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario, a 3-year-old child is likely to have received the 4th dose (1st booster)of the diphtheria vaccine between 16-24 months of age according to National ImmunizationSchedule (i.e., 16 months ago). Since he has received a booster dose within 5 years,only erythromycin is indicated in case of close contact with the diphtheria patient.All household contacts with diphtheria patients should be closely monitored for 7 days. Cultureshould be taken from both the throat and nose. All contacts should receive antibiotic prophylaxis(benzathine penicillin G or erythromycin), regardless of immunization status.Children who have not received a booster dose of the diphtheria toxoid vaccine within 5 yearsshould be given the vaccine in an age-appropriate form. Children who have not yet received their4th dose should be vaccinated accordingly.If fewer than three doses of diphtheria toxoid have been given, or vaccination history is unknown,an immediate dose of diphtheria toxoid should be given and the primary series completedaccording to the current schedule.Asymptomatic carriers of diphtheria are treated with antimicrobial prophylaxis for a period of10-14 days. If an individual has not received a booster dose of diphtheria toxoid within 1 year, anage-appropriate preparation of the vaccine should be administered promptly.Droplet precautions (respiratory colonization) or contact precautions (cutaneous colonization) ofcases and carriers are maintained until two consecutive negative cultures (collected 24 hoursapart) are obtained after cessation of therapy.

questions.question: A young boy is brought to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and painfulstraining for 4 months. The symptoms were accompanied by rectal prolapse. Stoolexamination showed the following finding. Infection with which of the following helminths ismost likely?302
questions.explanation: The image shows a barrel-shaped ovum, which along with rectal prolapse is characteristicof trichuris trichiura.Trichuriasis is caused by T. trichiura (whipworm), which inhabits the cecum and ascending colon.They bury their thin heads into the intestinal lining causing edema, loosening the elasticepithelium, and weakening the surrounding muscles. This leads to loss of supports and rectalprolapse. Other clinical features include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth, anddevelopmental defects.Diagnosis is done by fecal smears showing the barrel-shaped ovum of T. trichiura.The image below shows the barrel-shaped ovum of Trichuris trichiura.317Albendazole is the drug of choice (400 mg, orally, for 3 days; for all ages).

questions.question: An anxious mother brought her 4-year-old daughter to the pediatrician. The girl was passingloose, bulky stools for the past 4 days. This was often associated with pain in the abdomen.The pediatrician ordered stool examination, which showed the following organisms. Whichvitamin deficiency is the child at the greatest risk for?10 μm303
questions.explanation: The stool examination (image) shows pear-shaped trophozoites having two nuclei and a flagellum,typical of Giardia lamblia. Giardiasis is associated with a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins likevitamin A.Giardia lamblia is transmitted via contaminated drinking water.Clinical features include acute infectious diarrhea or chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive, andabdominal pain. Stools initially may be profuse and watery and later become greasy andfoul-smelling. Stools do not contain blood, mucus, or leukocytes. It is associated with fat-solublevitamin deficiencies, iron deficiency, and growth stunting.Diagnosis is done by stool enzyme immunoassay (EIA) or direct fluorescent antibody tests forGiardia antigens; EIA is superior to microscopy.Treatment includes tinidazole and nitazoxanide.

questions.question: In a child, the amoebic liver abscess can be diagnosed by demonstrating which of thefollowing?

options.C: Cysts in the hepatic venous sample

questions.explanation: The amoebic liver abscess can be diagnosed by demonstrating Trophozoites in the pusAmebiasis is caused by Entamoeba histolytica. Trophozoites are responsible for tissue invasionand destruction.Amoebic Colitis will present as colicky abdominal pains and frequent bowel movements (6-8/day).Diarrhea is associated with tenesmus, heme-positive stool. Trophozoites invade the intestinalmucosa and produce flask-shaped ulcers.318Amoebic liver abscess occurs in <1% infected individuals. Fever is the hallmark of amoebic liverabscess. It is associated with abdominal pain, abdominal distention and enlargement, andtenderness of the liver. Changes at the base of the right lung, such as elevation of the diaphragmand atelectasis or effusion, can also occur. The most common finding is a single abscess in theright hepatic lobe, detected on USG, CT, or MRI.The image below shows a CT scan of a right lobe liver abscess.RA0Invasive amebiasis is treated with nitroimidazoles such as metronidazole or tinidazole. This isfollowed by a luminal amebicide such as paromomycin.

questions.question: What is the most common route of acquiring Ancylostoma duodenale infection?
questions.explanation: Skin penetration is the most common route by which the larva of Ancylostomaduodenale (hookworm) enters the human body.Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) larvae enter the human host by skin penetration andundergo extraintestinal migration through the venous circulation to the lungs. They enter alveoliand climb up to the bronchial tree and pharynx, and are swallowed. Larvae reach the smallintestine and become adult worms.Clinical manifestations include iron deficiency anemia, resulting from chronic occult intestinalblood loss. Dermatitis, sometimes referred to as ground itch, may occur when they penetratehuman skin. Eosinophilic pneumonia can also be seen.Infection with a zoonotic hookworm, especially Ancylostoma braziliense, can result in the lateralmigration of the larvae causing cutaneous tracts of cutaneous larva migrans.The image below shows the lifecycle of the intestinal hookworm.319ODPDXIntestinal Hookworm3Development tofilariform larva inenviornmentRhabditiform larvahatchesInfective stageDiagnostic stageFilariform larvapenetrates skinC D CLarvae exit circulationin the lungs; they arethen coughed up andswallowed.Eggs in fecesThe image given below shows cutaneous larva migrans.5Ancylostoma spp. larvaecan become developmentallyarrested and dormant in tissues.Re-activated larvae may enterthe small intestine.Adults in small intestineAncylostoma Ancylostoma Necatorduodenale ceylanicum americanusTreatment:• Mebendazole 100 mg bid, orally, for 3 days or single dose of 500 mg•Albendazole 400 mg, orally, once

questions.question: A child from Bihar comes with a fever. Blood examination shows sheathed microfilaria asshown in the image. Identify the organism.304
questions.explanation: The incidence of Brugia malayi is more in children from Bihar and the image showing microfilariawith two nuclei at the tail. Hence the organism is Brugia malayi, which causes lymphatic filariasis.Brugia malayi (Malayan filariasis), Brugia timori, and Wuchereria bancrofti (bancroftian filariasis)are thread-like nematodes that cause a similar infection called Filariasis. Infective larvae are320introduced into humans during sucking of blood by the mosquito vector (commonly, culex).Clinical manifestations include episodic fever, lymphangitis of an extremity, lymphadenitis(especially the inguinal and axillary areas), headaches, and myalgias. Hepatosplenomegaly andgeneralized lymphadenopathy are often seen in children. These symptoms are caused by an acuteinflammatory response triggered by the death of adult worms.Diagnosis is done by demonstration of microfilariae in the blood. Blood samples should beobtained between 10 pm and 2 am because microfilaremia is nocturnal.Treatment:.Diethylcarbamazine 1 mg/kg PO as a single dose on day 1• 1 mg/kg tid on day 2• 1-2mg/kg tid on day 3•6 mg/kg/day divided tid on days 4-14The image below shows the difference between microfilaria of various filarial nematodes.MDifference between microfilarifilarial nematodos.RNocturnal periodicity – Shoathod, the tail-tip free from nuoleiNocturnal periodicityShoothod. two disonsto nuclei.one at antrome tip and the other midrange betweenthe tip and posterior column of nuclei– Vactori MansoniaADiurnal periodicity• Vootor:- Sheathed, nusleiChrysops (mango fIV).@MARROVAVA

questions.question: A boy is brought to the emergency with repeated episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures.History is significant for a dietary intake of pork. MRI reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesionsas shown below. Which of the following organism is the likely cause for seizures in thispatient?305
questions.explanation: The likely cause of seizures in a child who has multiple ring-enhancing lesions and dietary historyof pork intake is an infection with Taenia solium.Children acquire the adult form of the parasite by ingestion of undercooked pork containinglarvae cysts. In the intestines, the cyst converts into adult form. The adult form releases eggs inthe stool.If the eggs are ingested (shed by tapeworm carriers or by unhygienic practices), the larvae arereleased from the eggs. The larva then invades through the intestines and migrate through thebloodstream to the muscles (and other organs), where they form tissue cysts called cysticercosis.When these larvae find their way to the brain, it is termed as neurocysticercosis.321Neurocysticercosis typically presents with seizures (focal or generalized). It can be associated withbasilar arachnoiditis that can present with signs of meningeal irritation. Cysticerci in the tissuesmay present with focal findings from the mass effect. Ocular neurocysticercosis causes decreasedvisual acuity because of cysticerci in the retina or vitreous, retinal detachment, or iridocyclitis.Treatment includes management of seizures. albendazole therapy (treatment of choice).Praziquantel can also be used.

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding congenital toxoplasmosis?

options.A: It occurs through hematogenous dissemination to the placenta
options.B: Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation
options.D: It can manifests as hydrops fetalis

questions.explanation: IgG is not diagnostic for congenital toxoplasmosis.The presence of IgG antibodies in a newborn can be due to an old infection in the mother, as IgGcan cross the placenta. IgM cannot cross the placenta, hence the presence of IgM in newbornsconfirms the diagnosis of congenital toxoplasmosis. IgM immunosorbent agglutination assay(ISAGA) and IgA ELISA are the most useful diagnostic tests.Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondi. Toxoplasma can be transmitted to humans bythree principal routes:• Ingestion of raw or inadequately cooked infected meat••Ingestion of oocysts through exposure to cat litter or soilNewly infected pregnant woman passing the infection to her unborn fetusIt can be acquired orally, transplacentally or rarely, parenterally or by transfusion.Congenital toxoplasmosis: When a mother acquires the infection during gestation, organisms maydisseminate hematogenously to the placenta. Infection may be transmitted to the fetustransplacentally or during vaginal delivery.The characteristic triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and cerebral calcifications may bepresent. Other clinical features include small size for gestational age, prematurity, persistentjaundice, mild thrombocytopenia, hydrops fetalis, and perinatal death.

questions.question: The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is
questions.explanation: Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis.The characteristic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis is chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and diffuseintracranial calcifications. Clinical manifestations apart from the triad include hydrops fetalis,intrauterine growth retardation, prematurity, peripheral retinal scars, persistent jaundice, andmild thrombocytopenia.Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs when a pregnant woman acquires the infection during gestation.The organism may cross to the fetus transplacentally or at the time of vaginal delivery. Theseverity of the disease in the neonate is greater if the woman gets infected early in herpregnancy. The causative agent is Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular protozoan.322The diagnosis is made by the detection of IgM anti-toxoplasma antibodies. IgG can cross theplacenta is hence, cannot confirm infection in the infant. IgM immunosorbent agglutination assay(ISAGA) and IgA ELISA are the most useful diagnostic tests.Spiramycin can be administered for cases of acute infection in early pregnancy to reduce verticaltransmission. It does not cross the placenta and therefore cannot be used to treat an infectedfetus. Pyrimethamine-sulfonamide (to be avoided in the first trimester) is used when a fetalinfection is confirmed or in maternal infections after 18 weeks.

questions.question: Maternal antibodies that do not provide significant immunity in a neonate:
questions.explanation: Maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity to polio infection in a neonate.Administering an oral polio vaccine (OPV) dose at birth can provide early mucosal protection,safeguarding against enteric pathogens before they can hinder the intestinal mucosal immuneresponse. Furthermore, administering OPV during the period when infants are protected bymaternal antibodies may help prevent vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP).All pregnant women should receive a tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellularpertussis (Tdap) vaccine during each pregnancy, as early in the 27-36-week-of-gestation windowas possible. The maternal antibodies formed from Tdap will provide immunity against tetanus,diphtheria, and pertussis in the newborn. Administering the Tdap vaccine earlier, between the27th and 36th week of gestation, maximizes the transfer of passive antibodies to the infant(options A and C).Infants less than 6 months are generally protected from measles by maternal antibodies (optionD).

questions.question: What is the daily dosage of ethambutol for an adolescent of age 14 years?
questions.explanation: The daily dosage of ethambutol is 20 mg/kg body weight.First-line antitubercular drugs:Note:• All first-line antitubercular drugs are hepatotoxic except ethambutol.●All first-line antitubercular drugs are bactericidal except ethambutol, which is bacteriostatic.DrugDaily dosage(mg/k Adverse effectsg)Isoniazid10-15Rifampin 15-20Ethambut20olPeripheral neuritis, hepatic enzyme elevationOrange discoloration of secretions andurineOptic neuritis, decreased red-green color discrimination323DrugDaily dosage(mg/k Adverse effectsg)Pyrazinamide30-40Hepatotoxicity, hyperuricemia

questions.question: Which of the following is not a component of Hutchinson's triad in congenital syphilis?
